problem:
Classify the view of this echocardiography image into: AP2, AP3, AP4, AP5, PLAX, RVIF, SUBC4, SUBC5, SUBIVC, PSAXAo PSAXM, PSAXPM, PSAXAp, SUPRA.
 Provide reasoning: Justify your classification based on the following key elements:
- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures

- Key Structures: Identify which anatomical structures are visible in the image. Options include:
  - Left Atrium (LA)
  - Right Atrium (RA)
  - Left Ventricle (LV)
  - Right Ventricle (RV)
  - Mitral Valve
  - Tricuspid Valve
  - Aortic Valve (AV)
  - Left Ventricular Outflow Tract (LVOT)
  - Inferior Vena Cava (IVC)
  - Papillary Muscles
  - Aortic Arch and its branches
- Orientation: Determine the orientation of the heart in the image. Options include:
  - Apex of the heart at the top
  - Circular cross-sectional view of the heart
  - Long axis of the heart
  - Subcostal view (heart viewed from beneath)
  - Superior view (viewing the aortic arch from above)
- Distinguishing Features: Highlight distinguishing features that help identify the view. Options include:
  - Presence of two, three, or four chambers
  - Visibility of valves (e.g., mitral, tricuspid, aortic)
  - Visibility of specific vessels (e.g., IVC, aortic arch)
  - Presence of papillary muscles or LVOT
  - Relative sizes and positions of the visible structures
